|Title=Knowing the risk factors for the onset of macroangiopathic disorders
|Description=None
|Section=Follow-up and/or prognosis
|Contributors=Gaetan Prévost,Eva Feigerlova,Hélène Bihan,Etienne Larger,Claire Briet
|Order=7}}

The macrovascular damage caused by diabetes is concentrated in the heart (risk of coronary heart disease X2 to 4) and the large vessels (risk of OIA X5 and risk of stroke X2).

The pathophysiology shares many similarities with non-diabetic atheroma, although a few clinical differences can be identified in diabetic patients: onset at an earlier age, lesions that are often more extensive and less symptomatic (less neuropathy-related pain).


Follow-up studies have shown that the risk factors for macrovascular disease in T2DM patients, after adjustment for age and sex, are as follows

1/ glycaemic control (HbA1c)

2/ lipid balance (especially LDL, but also low HDL) [[Analyse du bilan lipidique SD-195]]

3/ Blood pressure balance (systolic BP) [[Hypertension SD-042]] [[Hypertension in adults and children]]

4/Smoking [[Prevention of tobacco-related risks SD-314]]  [[Male/female smoking 2C-075-PE-A02]]

question.title: What is a key risk factor for macrovascular disease in patients with type 2 diabetes?

option_a.title: Poor insulin sensitivity
option_a.description: A factor that can contribute to the development of insulin resistance

option_b.title: High blood pressure
option_b.description: A well-established risk factor for cardiovascular disease

option_c.title: Low HDL cholesterol
option_c.description: A risk factor for cardiovascular disease, especially in diabetic patients

option_d.title: Age
option_d.description: A risk factor for many diseases, including cardiovascular disease

correct_option.title: High blood pressure
correct_option.description: A well-established risk factor for macrovascular disease in diabetic patients
